title: USS Gasconade (APA-85)
text:
USS "Gasconade" (APA-85) was a <a href="Gilliam%20class%20attack%20transport">"Gilliam"-class</a> <a href="attack%20transport">attack transport</a> that served with the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> from 1944 to 1946. She was sunk as a target in 1948.
History.
"Gasconade" was named after a county in <a href="Gasconade%20County%2C%20Missouri">Missouri</a>. She was laid down 7 November 1944 under <a href="Maritime%20Commission">Maritime Commission</a> contract by the <a href="Consolidated%20Steel%20Corporation">Consolidated Steel Corporation</a> at <a href="Wilmington%2C%20Los%20Angeles">Wilmington, Los Angeles</a>; launched 23 January 1945; acquired by the Navy 10 March 1945, and commissioned 11 March 1945 at <a href="San%20Pedro%2C%20Los%20Angeles">San Pedro, Los Angeles</a>, Lt. Comdr. Allen E. Stiff in command.
World War II.
After shakedown, "Gasconade" departed <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a> 8 May on a troop transport voyage to the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a>. Steaming via <a href="Pearl%20Harbor">Pearl Harbor</a>, <a href="Eniwetok">Eniwetok</a>, and <a href="Ulithi">Ulithi</a>, she arrived <a href="Samar">Samar</a> 3 June. Loaded with mail and cargo, she steamed to San Francisco from 18 June to 6 July; thence transported additional troops to the Philippines. Arriving Leyte Gulf 2 August, she served as receiving ship until mid-August when she proceeded to <a href="Manila%20Bay">Manila Bay</a> to stage for the Allied occupation of <a href="Japan">Japan</a>.
Post-war.
"Gasconade" departed Manila 20 August; and, as part of a huge transport task force carrying the first sea-borne occupation forces to Japan, she entered <a href="Tokyo%20Bay">Tokyo Bay</a> 2 September while surrender terms were being signed on board . She debarked her troops at <a href="United%20States%20Fleet%20Activities%20Yokosuka">Yokosuka</a> 3 September; steamed to the Philippines from 4 to 11 September, then carried more occupation troops from <a href="Mindanao">Mindanao</a> to <a href="Kure%2C%20Hiroshima">Kure</a>, Japan, from 19 September to 6 October.
Operation Magic Carpet.
After returning to <a href="Leyte%20Gulf">Leyte Gulf</a> 11 October, "Gasconade" embarked military passengers and sailed for the United States 17 October as part of <a href="Operation%20Magic%20Carpet">Operation Magic Carpet</a>. She reached <a href="Portland%2C%20Oregon">Portland, Oregon</a>, 2 November, transported occupation troops to <a href="Nagoya">Nagoya</a>, Japan, 18 November to 5 December; and sailed 8 December on another Magic Carpet voyage, arriving <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a> 19 December. After carrying a garrison force to <a href="Guam">Guam</a> from 13 to 29 January 1946, she voyaged to Pearl Harbor from 30 January to 8 February with returning veterans embarked.
Operation Crossroads.
Assigned to Joint Task Force 1, "Gasconade" during the next 3 months prepared for <a href="Operation%20Crossroads">Operation Crossroads</a>, a program of <a href="atomic%20bomb">nuclear tests</a> in the <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshall Islands</a>. Departing Pearl Harbor 18 May in company with Transport Division 92, she reached <a href="Bikini%20Atoll">Bikini Atoll</a>, Marshalls, 30 May. On 22 June her crew transferred to . Designated a target ship for the experiments, she survived an atomic blast 18 July.
Decommissioning and fate.
"Gasconade" decommissioned in the Marshall Islands 28 August. In December she was taken in tow at <a href="Kwajalein">Kwajalein</a> for transfer to the United States, where she arrived San Francisco 27 January 1947. After undergoing structural and <a href="radioactivity">radioactivity</a> tests, she was redesignated a target ship in March 1948. She was sunk by <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es 21 July in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a> off lower <a href="California">California</a>.
